examples.explanation: The medium is a decoy. It's asymmetrically dominated by the largefor just 50 cents more, you get much more popcorn. This makes the large seem like an obvious great deal. Without the medium, customers would compare small vs. large and more would choose small. The decoy shifts preferences toward the higher-margin large size.
examples.takeaway: When you see pricing tiers, identify the decoy. Which option is clearly inferior to another? That's not there to be chosenit's there to make another option look better.

examples.title: The IKEA Bookshelf
examples.scenario: You spend 3 hours assembling a bookshelf from IKEA, getting frustrated, making mistakes, and finally completing it. Your neighbor buys an identical bookshelf pre-assembled for the same price. A month later, you're moving. Your neighbor sells their bookshelf at market price. You can't bear to part with yoursyou'd want at least double what it's worth.
examples.question: Why do you value your bookshelf more than an identical one? Is this rational?
examples.explanation: The IKEA effect shows that labor creates lovewe value things more when we've invested effort in creating them, regardless of the objective quality of the result. Your frustration and effort became embedded in the bookshelf. It's not rational in market terms, but it's a predictable psychological response. The labor itself generated valuefor you.
examples.takeaway: For products: let users participate in creation to increase perceived value. For yourself: recognize that your emotional attachment to things you built may not reflect their actual worth.

examples.title: The Hotel Stay
examples.scenario: Guest A stays at a hotel. Day 1 is okay. Day 2 has a major problemthe AC breaks in summer. Day 3, the hotel fixes it and upgrades them to a suite as an apology. Guest B stays at the same hotel. All three days are consistently goodnice room, no problems, standard service. Guest A rates the hotel higher than Guest B.
examples.question: The guest who had a problem rates the hotel higher than the guest with no problems. What explains this counterintuitive result?
examples.explanation: The Peak-End Rule says we judge experiences by their peak (most intense moment) and ending, not the average. Guest A's peak was the suite upgrade and personal attention; their ending was excellent. Guest B had no peaksjust consistent okayness. The memory of the experience, which drives ratings and return visits, favors dramatic highs and strong endings over uniformity.
examples.takeaway: Design experiences with memorable peaks and strong endings. A consistently okay experience may be remembered worse than one with problems that were dramatically resolved.

examples.title: The Limited Edition
examples.scenario: A sneaker brand announces a new shoe: 'Limited to 500 pairs. One per customer. Available Saturday 9 AM.' People line up overnight. The shoes sell out in 90 seconds. Resale prices hit 10x retail within hours. The shoes are objectively identical to a standard model with a different colorway.
examples.question: The shoes aren't betterjust scarcer. Why does artificial limitation increase desire so dramatically?
examples.explanation: Scarcity signals value (rare things must be valuable) and triggers loss aversion (fear of missing the opportunity). The limitation creates competition, social proof (if others want it, it must be good), and a deadline that forces immediate action. The sneakers aren't scarce because they're valuablethey're perceived as valuable because they're scarce.
examples.takeaway: Recognize artificial scarcity as a persuasion tactic. Ask: 'Would I want this if it were abundantly available?' Your urgency may be manufactured.

examples.title: The Free Trial Trap
examples.scenario: A software company offers a 30-day free trial. You sign up, configure it for your workflow, import your data, learn the interface. Day 28, you get a reminder: 'Your trial ends in 2 days. Enter payment to keep your settings and data.' You hadn't planned to subscribe, but now you're entering your credit card.
examples.question: Why is converting from free trial so effective? What would make it easier to walk away?
examples.explanation: After 30 days, you feel ownership (endowment effect). The decision isn't 'should I buy this?'it's 'should I lose what I already have?' (loss aversion). Plus, you've invested time configuring it, and abandoning that investment feels inconsistent with your past effort (commitment and consistency).
examples.takeaway: Before starting free trials, decide your criteria for subscribing. At the end, ask: 'Knowing what I know now, would I choose to buy this from scratch?' Don't let temporary ownership cloud permanent decisions.

examples.title: The Presentation Middle
examples.scenario: You attend a 60-minute presentation. The speaker opens with a powerful story. The middle 40 minutes cover important details. The conclusion has a memorable call to action. A week later, you remember the opening story and the call to action. The middle? Mostly gone.
examples.question: How should this affect how you structure important communications?
examples.explanation: The serial position effect means items at the beginning (primacy) and end (recency) are remembered better than the middle. The peak-end rule adds that the most intense moment matters disproportionately. Your important points should go at the beginning, end, or as a designed 'peak moment'not buried in the middle.
examples.takeaway: Structure communications with openings and closings that carry your key messages. If critical information must go in the middle, make it distinctive. Never end with Q&Aend with your message.

examples.title: The Privacy Settings
examples.scenario: A social media app has 47 privacy settings. Most users never touch them. The company's defaults: share everything with everyone, allow data collection for advertising, enable location tracking. Users who would choose more privacy if asked simply... don't ask. They accept defaults.
examples.question: If users would prefer more privacy, why don't they change the settings? How should ethical companies handle this?
examples.explanation: Default bias means people stick with pre-selected options. Cognitive load from evaluating 47 settings is overwhelming. The defaults carry implicit endorsement ('this must be what's normal'). Changing requires active effort; accepting requires none. Together, these forces mean most users accept whatever privacy invasion is defaulted.
examples.takeaway: Companies: choose defaults that serve users, not just engagement metrics. Users: audit your defaults periodically. The settings you never changed were chosen by someone elsewith their interests in mind.

examples.title: The Surgery Decision
examples.scenario: A doctor tells Patient A: 'This surgery has a 90% survival rate.' Patient B is told: 'This surgery has a 10% mortality rate.' Both patients have the same surgery recommended. Patient A agrees immediately. Patient B asks for alternatives and second opinions.
examples.question: The statistics are identical. Why do patients respond so differently?
examples.explanation: The framing effect shows that how information is presented changes decisions. '90% survival' frames it as a gain; '10% mortality' frames it as a loss. Loss aversion means the loss frame (dying) has more psychological weight than the equivalent gain frame (surviving). Same facts, different frames, different decisions.
examples.takeaway: When receiving information, reframe it yourself. Convert percentages both ways. Ask: 'Would I decide differently if this were presented differently?' If yes, the frame is affecting you more than the facts.

examples.title: The Loyalty Card Progress
examples.scenario: Coffee shop A gives you a card: 'Buy 10 coffees, get one free.' You have an empty card with 10 stamps to collect. Coffee shop B gives you a card: 'Buy 12 coffees, get one free'but it already has 2 stamps. Both require 10 purchases. Customers at Shop B complete their cards 34% faster.
examples.question: Both cards require the same number of purchases. Why do pre-stamped cards get completed faster?
examples.explanation: The goal gradient effect shows we accelerate as we approach goals. Starting with 2/12 stamps feels closer to completion than 0/10, even though the remaining distance is identical. The pre-filled stamps also create a sense of ownership (endowment effect)you already 'have' progress you don't want to lose.
examples.takeaway: When designing progress systems, give users a head start. When pursuing goals yourself, find ways to make the goal feel closerreframe your progress in terms of what you've done, not just what remains.

examples.title: The Bad Review Vortex
examples.scenario: A product has 100 reviews: 90 five-star, 10 one-star. Shoppers spend most of their time reading the one-star reviews. A single detailed negative review makes them hesitate on a product with 90% positive ratings. The company responds helpfully to the criticism, but the damage feels disproportionate.
examples.question: Why do negative reviews have outsized impact? What can the company do?
examples.explanation: Negativity bias means bad information carries more weight than equivalent good information. One negative review isn't balanced by one positiveit takes roughly 5 positive reviews to offset one negative. Shoppers aren't irrational; they're adapting to a world where losses (bad purchases) hurt more than equivalent gains (good purchases) feel good.
examples.takeaway: For businesses: prioritize eliminating sources of bad reviews over generating good ones. The ratio mattersbut preventing negatives is more valuable than generating positives.

examples.title: The End-of-Day Diet Collapse
examples.scenario: You start each day committed to healthy eating. Breakfast: great choices. Lunch: healthy selection. By 7 PM, you're exhausted from work decisionswhat to prioritize, how to respond to emails, which meetings to schedule. You order pizza and eat ice cream from the carton. Tomorrow, the same pattern repeats.
examples.question: Your commitment doesn't change throughout the day. What does?
examples.explanation: Decision fatigue depletes your mental resources throughout the day. Each decision at workeven small onesdraws from the same limited pool that diet willpower requires. By evening, the tank is empty. You're not less committed; you're mentally exhausted. The pizza isn't a character failureit's a resource depletion problem.
examples.takeaway: Make important decisions early in the day. Reduce trivial decisions (meal prep, routines, automation). Recognize evening vulnerability and plan for itdon't rely on willpower when the tank is empty.

examples.title: The Commitment Escalation
examples.scenario: A charity asks if you support clean water for children. You say yes. They ask if you'd sign a petition. You do. They ask if you'd put a small window sticker on your car. Sure. They ask for a $20 monthly donation. You find yourself saying yeseven though you didn't intend to commit financially when you signed the petition.
examples.question: How did signing a petition lead to a monthly donation? What principle explains this escalation?
examples.explanation: The commitment and consistency principle shows that once we take a position, we feel pressure to behave consistently with it. Each small yes changed your self-image: you became 'someone who supports this cause.' Refusing the donation would be inconsistent with that identity. The charity didn't start bigthey started small and escalated.
examples.takeaway: Recognize foot-in-the-door tactics. Small commitments change your self-image, making larger requests feel consistent. It's okay to say: 'I agreed to the petition, but I'm not committing to more right now.'
